reviewText: Whenever there is a highlighted, foreign-themed movie in Hollywood, there is often undue praise - simply for the fact that it's far from the typical American-centric aspect of most movies.  In the case of Memoirs of a Geisha, it's quite possible that the adoration is justified, and I'm kicking myself for not watching this sooner.Powerful enough in and of itself, the movie tells the story of a young girl named Chiyo (Ziyi Zhang) who endures incredible hardships through life.  Sold at a young age to be a geisha, placed in a power struggle against other geishas, and facing countless obstacles in her rise to being a powerful, elegant geisha named Sayuri - the most sought after of all - the timeline and transformation from Chiyo to SAYURI is breathtaking.  Training with the elegant and patient Mameha (Michelle Yeoh), and later against Hatsumomo (Li Gong) - a character as gorgeous as she is vicious - forges Sayuri's will to succeed.  Additionally, the climb to the top gets her involved and rubbing elbows with a Baron (the always interesting Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa) and the Chairman (Ken Watanabe), for whom she immediately feels strong feelings.  The true stars of this movie, however, may not even be the collection of beautiful actresses; but, instead, everything inanimate.Slightly overshadowing the actors are the glamorous costumes, and extravagant manner in which the geisha are adorned and decorated.  To see their presence is to almost understand how they were able to capture men's attention with a mere glance.  Additional credit must be given to the outstanding cinematography and musical score, as nearly every scene is a stunning sight or sound that only amplifies the beauty of Asian culture.Incredibly well told and acted, detailed and mysterious at the same time, it's an original movie that delves into a somewhat secretive culture not too far removed, and in many ways still prevalent in the patriarchal Japanese society.  It's one of the more exotic and beautiful movies ever made.  The only downside I could see was the mix-up of Asian races, and the unfortunately necessity of making actresses speak broken English rather than Japanese (because most of the main stars are Chinese).

reviewText: For my money, "Memoirs of a Geisha" is a near perfect movie. It is stylistically beautiful and filled with gorgeous images. Its plot, of a young girl sold to become a geisha, is riveting. The film's score, by John Williams, is first rate. And by the end, you learn something about the values of the geisha -- a heightened form of feminine perfection that appealed to Japanese men (and others) through the war years. The movie is set in the years just before and after World War II. Young Chiyo, the daughter of a poor fisherman, is torn from her family and placed in an "okiyo" -- home to a geisha and training ground for future geishas. Life is hard and pointless until Chiyo one days meets a powerful businessman who takes an interest in her. Chiyo swears to be part of his entourage. Fate intervenes, and she is taken in by an older geisha who takes an interest in her. A rival geisha plots her downfall.I was fascinated by the way the film depicted the precarious world of the geisha. As an epitome of sexual desire, she was tainted by sexual experience -- real or perceived. Clothed and made up to perfection, she was expected to be demure in the presence of men, but subtly challenging and clever a well. The fine line that women have toed or millennia.A wonderful movie. reviewText: I was able to watch this film last night and I ask you this...............Can a group of American men and Chinese actresses render the remote and mysterious world of a geisha? The answer is yes, with stunning beauty ...and regrettable flaws. The basic flaw of the film is the dialogue that feels so foreign it might have been written in another language. The different accents of the cast doesn't help matters because they speak in a sort of British English that is a distraction. I was actually wishing for subtitles at certain points of the film.Truth be told, this movie was not as bad as its trailer led me to expect. It had a story to tell (although it crumbles in the end), images to show, and material to present. There were ample displays of exquisite beauty--the trailing tails of silk kimonos, the subtle allure of hand gestures, and the captivating kabuki theater dance scene...On the other hand, the American director was not able to pull the Japanese out of Chinese actresses. (This movie was so crowded by famous Chinese idols that I found myself inadvertently searching for Joan Chen among the cast.) To be fair, all three main actors (Gong Li in particular) show strong performances that made me sympathetic to Rob Marshall's choices. However, they remain utterly Chinese throughout this movie. The look and accent are not the only problems. They lacked the kind of extreme femininity, excessive felicity, and delicately mechanical gesture, posture, and movements of traditional Japanese ladies you can see in custom dramas of Japanese production. (Michelle Yeoh seems to be the only one trying a little bit of those, but it did not quite work for some reason.)So, let me re-address the question: Can a group of American men and Chinese actresses render the world of a geisha? The answer, I guess, really depends on what you are looking for. If you would like a little bit of delight from an aesthetically pleasing picture with a vague standard for authenticity and realism, this movie delivers it. I would not say Rob Marshall failed completely. Memoirs of a Geisha is not the first, nor the last, movie that subjects another culture to the crude lens of American exoticism. It definitely is not the worst one.

reviewText: In many ways, "Memoirs of a Geisha" is exactly how you think it is: it is full of beautiful scenery, sensitive music, poetic voiceovers, and the like.  And though predictably present, all those things are well done and enjoyable to sit through.  However, I'm glad to report that there's also a nice little potboiler plot that builds up along the way, as rival geisha plot against one another for control of their house.  That provides a good bit of viewing fun.It's also interesting to note the differences between Western culture and Japanese culture, or at least the culture of the geisha circa World War II.  For example, the ultimate romantic goal of a geisha is to secure one successful and respectable man to be her lifelong sponsor, a man she could dote over and pamper in return for financial security.  Of course, most of the time the men who are most desirable as sponsors are long married with families.  "Why are these geisha getting all misty eyed over these men who already have wives?" my wife asked.  "Don't be judgemental, darling," I replied with a smile.If you liked the original book (I listened to the excellent unabridged audiobook version of the story a few years ago and enjoyed it), you'll probably like the movie, which adapts the long novel as well as any normal-length movie probably can.  Also, the two-disc DVD set delivers a generous amount of extra features.In the end, even if this isn't the type of movie you'd normally seek out (I guess I'm mainly talking to the men out there), there's much to enjoy about "Memoirs of a Geisha".  So, do yourself a favor and pick it up to watch with your wife or significant other: you'll score some points for selecting a movie that your partner will actually enjoy, and you'll likely end up being entertained by it, too.

reviewText: Having read "Memoirs of a Geisha," I was expecting great things from the film version. Positioned as a heavyweight Oscar contender last year, it's chances were derailed by generally moderate to unenthusiastic reviews. I, therefore, decided to give it a pass in the theaters and catch it later with fresh eyes. Well, there is good news and bad news with "Memoirs"--but probably much of what I have to say won't be "new" news"Memoirs" is far from an inept picture. It is absolutely stunning. The visuals, art direction, cinematography, costumes--it's all top notch. Technically speaking, this is a very accomplished film. Anyone who has an interest in these aspects will be greatly rewarded. I, also, thought the performances were quite good. I know there was a bit of controversy about the actual nationalities of the actor's involved--but this was not something that affected my impression of the film. It's not particularly unheard of in Hollywood to put "name" talent into your picture. If having these accomplished international actors helped "Memoirs" get it's backing, that's just a realistic part of Hollywood as a business.While I did think the performances were dignified, there was just something a little lifeless about the movie. I watched with interest throughout the film, but I never really felt any emotion for the proceedings. It's pretty, but somewhat empty. Only Gong Li as a supercharged villain seemed to be having any fun. I think everyone was so concerned with making an austere "classic," they forgot the energy and the heart and the passion. I wanted to be swept up, but it never happens. I got detached admiration, instead.Look, I'm not going to be super critical. It's a bit unfair when people say the movie has ruined the book, etc. You're always treading dangerous ground when you adapt a beloved novel to the big screen and the inevitable comparisons are often unjust. I'll just say that the film version of "Memoirs" had all the potential to be a powerful modern romantic epic. But for all the lessons we get about Geishas, ultimately all we're left with is the protocol and not a glimpse of the real woman underneath the makeup. It's still interesting, but it's not moving.I'd rate this at 3 1/2 stars, which I'll round down in this case for the lost opportunities. KGHarris, 11/06.
summary: "Geisha" Suffers By Not Showing The Heart Of The Woman Beneath The Makeup

reviewText: A friend of mine loaned MEMOIRS OF A GEISHA to me, and I have to admit it sat on my shelf for months. The small font, singled spaced text was far from appealing to my eye. Thrown into the harsh world of the unknown, Chiyo soon realizes her only hope is to become a Geisha.MEMORIES OF A GEISHA takes the reader on Chiyo's journey from a young sister and daughter, to the aches, pains, and relentless training required to become a Geisha. reviewText: Three movies won three Oscars this year and one of those three was "Memoirs of a Geisha."  These were for the Art Direction by art director John Myrhe and set decorator Gretchen Rau, Dion Beebe's Cinematography, and Colleen Atwood's Costume Design.  Those particular awards should be sufficient to tell you that this is a gorgeous looking film, but once you see it you may well come to the conclusion that the style of the film is its most substantive part.  There is great beauty here, to be sure, but not the soul that would make it a great film.I have not read Arthur Golden's best-selling novel, but I am aware that those who have are not simply complaining that the book is better (a constant complaint applicable to almost all literature adapted to the screen), but saying that the script by Robin Swicord ("Practical Magic") has changed the novel into something inferior.  Obviously, I cannot speak to that, but I can comment on why this 2005 film proves to be less than satisfactory taken on its own terms.Young Chiyo (Suzuka Ohgo) and her sister are taken from their farming village and sold to a geisha house run by Mother (Kaori Momoi).  Chiyo ends up a possible candidate for becoming a geisha, although she has not idea what that means, while her sister, Satsu (Samantha Futerman) is immediately forced to work as a prostitute.  The geisha of the house, Hatsuomo (Li Gong), takes exception to the young girl and threatens to crush her.  But when she grows up, Chiyo (Ziyi Zhang), begins her training in earnest and is given the geisha name Sayuri, and is taken under the wing of the great geisha Mameha (Michelle Yeoh).The idea of training a geisha and the life they lived in Japan before World War II is a fascinating idea, but except for a stunning dance in artificial snow that is the highlight of the film, the training and the life ends up taking a back seat to a romantic plotline in the film.  As a young girl Chiyo first met the Chairman (Ken Watanabe), and her desire to become a geisha is entirely predicated on her belief that becoming one will bring her closer to the man she loves from afar.  Of course, the idea of love is antithetical to the ideals of the geisha, and a clear indication to my mind that Western sensibilities are going into play here.  The more Sayuri relies on her heart, the less I am attracted to the tale.  It is the denial of love that gives the geisha her pathos, and the example of Hatsuomo early on when she secretly meets with her love makes such indulgences to see quite tawdry.The Japanese sensibilities matter here because from our Western perspective this is the story of a woman who is sold into slavery to be a high priced courtesan.  Such a life is by definition better than dying on the street, but it is not a noble profession, and a woman who cannot give her heart is not allowed to be human.  The fact that geishas are not prostitutes is apparently not germane to the story.  True, after World War II many Japanese prostitutes presented themselves as Geishas and solidified that idea in the popular mind of Westerners, but a key selling point of "Memoirs of a Geisha" is that it immerses us into a foreign culture and failing to do so accurately is going to be a major mark against the effort for those who recognize the difference.  This is a movie that will disappoint you because you have a sense for how fine it could have been if it were telling a more ambitious tale.I would have liked this movie better if it ended a scene earlier, preferring the somewhat tragic ending of the sick joke that is played on Sayuri to the deus ex machina happy ending, which only serves to conform that this is much more a melodrama than any sort of epic.  The fact that the principle women are played by Chinese actresses rather than Japanese has more to do with the recognition of this particular trio of women from "Raise the Red Lantern" and "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon," than from their ethnicity.  It is undoubtedly too soon to say that Chinese and Japanese actresses can now be exchanged with the same ease that American and English actresses cross the Pond to find work.  Still, it is a beautiful movie and the DVD extras make watching it and gaining some small insights into the world it portrays worth the effort and justify rounding up.
summary: A beautiful film that loses it soul by Westernizing the tale too much

reviewText: I have taken some time to skim over the hundred prior reviews for this film currently to be found on Amazon.  This is usually a worthwhile exercise, and so I found it to be here.  I particularly commend the perceptive "Berk," who wrote the very first review.As might be expected, there is considerable variety of opinion, but there at least seems to be widely-held consensus that the film is visually stunning.  Although the casting of Chinese actresses in leading parts was controversial, it did not appear to do serious damage to the film in the minds of most reviewers.  Readers of the book seem to have been split down the middle as to whether the screenplay was adequately faithful to the printed version or disastrously untrue to it.  Some reviewers regarded "Memoirs of a Geisha" as a fairy tale, in particular a Cinderella story.It struck me as odd that reviewers did not make much of what was clearly the key scene of the whole movie, and clearly identified as such by the producers, since they highlighted it in virtually all their trailers and advertisements.  That, of course is the scene in which the newly adult heroine is informed that a true geisha needs only a single glance to make a man stop in his tracks.  The challenge being issued, the young woman immediately lavishes just such a glance on a poor shnook who happens to be riding by on a bicycle.  He is so stunned that he helplessly crashes into the first obstacle that presents itself--thus confirming the power of the geisha (and, alas, the general fate of all us poor shnooks.)A month ago, I underwent surgery for a hip replacement.  On the second day after the operation, being bed-ridden but wide-awake, I watched late night television.  The feature film on one of the national cable channels was "Show Girls," a movie I had often heard derided but had never seen.  Last night, my wife decided that the way to celebrate my emergence from medical care and rehab was to see "Memoirs of a Geisha" (which she had been longing to see for months.)  After a meal at a conveniently located Japanese restaurant, we ambled over to the downtown theater at which "Memoirs" is still in first-run.  About twenty minutes in, it struck me that I had already seen this tale of senseless rivalry between supposedly glamorous female entertainers at the upper end of the sex trade.  "Memoirs of a Geisha" is, at bottom, a remake of "Show Girls"--and not a very good one."Show Girls," as awful as it was, had a kind of loopy integrity.  It was faithful to its crackpot ideals.  The actresses (for want of a better term) were convincing in their loyalty to hard-bodied, clothing-optional shallowness.  They were honorably sleazy.  Their actions didn't make much sense, but they were the actions of people who actually do not make much sense in the real world.  "Memoirs" has none of that.In "Show Girls," the hostility of the established performer for the newcomer has some cockeyed justification.  In "Memoirs," it is a pointless malignancy that even Iago might question.In "Show Girls," the rival women have a physicality and sensuality (sleazy, of course, and more power to them for it!) that cannot be denied.  They certainly hold the eye, if not the mind.  In "Memoirs," there is nothing of the sort.  Oh, I can accept that sensuality in one culture does not necessarily translate into another--but this is an American film, based on an American book, guided by an American director on a set built in America.  There should be something for the American (and Canadian) audience.Consider that key scene.  The girl flashed THE LOOK and I felt ... nothing.  Audrey Hepburn could twinkle and whole battalions of men might figuratively clutch at their hearts and fall to their knees.  But from these actresses, and indeed the whole of "Memoirs," there came nothing, nothing at all.  That poor shnook must just have been a lousy bicycle rider.  The whole film was utterly lacking in sensuality, whether good or bad, even in those wholly gratuitous near-rape scenes.As for the visual beauty of the film, I must disagree.  Far too many scenes were murkily underlit and claustrophobic.  With a very few exceptions, exterior scenes were preposterously over-cluttered.  It may well be that this was a faithful reproduction of the reality in Japan in those days but, for Pete's sake, this was a fairy tale, a Cinderella story.  It should have looked like one.  Japan's Floating World was exquisitely captured in countless prints by the artists of the late Nineteenth and early Twentieth Centuries.  The truth of those images is far greater than mere dreary reality.  In the prints, the Floating World is an endlessly attractive and seductive otherworld, not the crowded, decaying wasteland shown in the film."Memoirs of a Geisha" is just another leaden, unconvincing, one-star Hollywood remake.  Do yourself a favor, rent the original, "Show Girls," and savor true Tinseltown integrity.
summary: Not nearly as good as the original

They managed, even the young girls who played the young Chiyo Chan & Pumpkin in the film.Some things were slightly different from the book to the film, which is obvious. Having the doctor deal with the cut on her leg had a lot more significance in the book, as it led up to the bidding war for her "mizuage" (virginity). Also the fact that her sister became a child prostitute was kinda glossed over in the book, but made more obvious in the film I thought. But Hatsumomo (played by Li Gong) came across even more nasty than in the book, and her eyes are so evil! Pumpkin suddenly becomes an American friendly prostitute and seems to belong in another movie altogether.The extras, unlike most films, are actually very informative, although I would have liked to have seen more of the makeup side of things - I absolutely love how they did the eyeliner - but still, the film actually makes you want to watch the extras. They're not your usual fluff.I think that Memoirs Of A Geisha will be even better on repeat viewings, and it's definitely one of my favourite movies. reviewText: Rob Marshall did an excellent job bringing Arthur Golden's novel to life on the big screen. "Memoirs of a Geisha" transports moviegoers to 1920s Japan, where a young girl named Chiyo (Ziyi Zhang) is sold to an okiya and overcomes numerous struggles to become one of the most prestigious geishas in all of Gion. With the help of Mameha, a successful geisha with a hidden agenda (Michelle Yeoh), the beautiful servant girl with striking blue-gray eyes transforms into the elegant Sayuri. The film is also a love story of sorts: Chiyo's chance meeting with the Chairman (Ken Watanbe) when she is a young girl is an event that shapes her destiny. However, as Mameha says in the film, women become geishas because they have no choice, and they are forced to make massive sacrifices because of it.The casting for this movie is spectacular. Critics have bashed this film because most of the main characters are played by Chinese actors, but they do an amazing job. (Plus, they're ACTORS! You don't have to actually BE a geisha in order to PLAY a geisha in a movie. Similarly, you do not have to BE Japanese in order to successfully PORTRAY a Japanese person in a film. People who have knocked this movie solely because of the cultural background of the actors are out of their minds.) I will be shocked if Zhang doesn't receive an Oscar nomination for her moving portrayal as Chiyo/Sayuri. Yeoh is perfect as the cool and collected Mameha, and Li Gong delivers an excellent performance as the beautiful and sadistic Hatsumomo.Visually, this movie is perfect. I've read Golden's novel and every aspect of the film looks exactly the way I pictured it when I was reading the book. As is the case with every book-to-movie adaptation, some material from the book always has to be cut. There were also a few things that differed from the book for no apparent reason. I thought some of the characters were toned down a bit for the film: Nobu wasn't as physically repulsive as he should have been and some of Hatsumomo's most vicious moments from the book aren't included in the movie, which is a shame. I also felt that the film didn't do a good enough job of thoroughly explaining the nature of the relationship between a geisha and her "danna." People who haven't read the book might be a bit confused by that whole thing. Finally, the ending of the movie was way too abrupt. The final pages of Golden's novel do a good job of explaining how Sayuri's relationship with the Chairman evolves over time. Remember, this is a man who is married and already has a family of his own: it's not like he and his geisha just walked off into the sunset and lived happily ever after together, which is the way the film made it out to be. There was a lot more to it than that, and I don't see why it wasn't presented more clearly in the movie.I think "Memoirs of a Geisha" is a good film adaptation of an excellent novel. My advice is that you read the book BEFORE seeing the movie: you'll enjoy the film more if you walk into the theatre with a sense of what's going on.
summary: Visually stunning, slightly lacking in content

reviewText: All the Japanoiserie aside, the basic story of "Memoirs of a Geisha" is as old as time: girl from the country makes good in the big city, loses it all then regains it by way of her talent, her wit and street smarts.The story of Chiyo/Sayuri (the amazing Ziyi Zhang) is told by director Rob Marshall ("Chicago") in a stoic, straightforward way with frankly not enough of the magic that the story deserves. There are numerous other Japanese, Chinese, and Korean actors well known in Asia but not in the U.S., which makes this almost a repertory effort. Why the main character, whose name changes, well a lot, is ripped from her home at the age of 9 to the life of only `potential geisha', if she can make it.  At this point you would think, as the movie seems to tell us, that being a geisha isn't easy.However, as someone who honestly got bored after 61 pages of the book, I have to say that the movie too was quite boring.  Especially since being a geisha, or at least learning about being one, seems just boring.  Yes, the rivalry between two `sister' geisha, is always there, but there is little doubt about who will win.  Then, there is the forbidden (for a geisha) and definitely pedophiliac love that the main geisha character ensues, but the audience is left with little surprise, and interest, there as well.All in all then, the movie does little to add to one's actual knowledge of geisha, (unless you never took a far east class somewhere along the line).  Moreover, this film is not that good of a period peace, since World War II, is almost left in the dust till the near end of the film.So ultimately, you may read the book perhaps, and maybe see the movie, but if you want to actually learn about the memoirs of geisha (yes I know this was fiction) then there are easier, and more entertaining ways to do so.

reviewText: I liked this film because of the interesting story line and the impressive visuals that the camera provides via costumes, sets, and creative photography. We see tough lifestyles and how the lead character, played very well by Zhang Ziyi, copes with her situation.  The problem with the story for me was that I never really saw what the hope was.  Are we supposed to root that she will be a geisha to someone she cares about although she can never marry them?  Also, the basis of the romance is a young girls fantasy coming from one chance encounter.  There are various scenes of conflict that are stressful, and moments of triumph that are wonderful, but in the end, where's the real hope?I personally felt that the film ends up a little empty because there was no real hope.  The hope of the lead character is not something that most of us would even consider positive.  In other films, even tragedies are tragedies because of some extinguished hope.  This film never has a real hope element to be extinguished.  The resulting emptiness keeps this from being a great film.Still, this is film worth watching and is a solid 3 1/2 star offering.

reviewText: I've always loved this movie and recently had the pleasure of reading the book.  That being said, I probably shouldn't have watched this directly after finishing the book.  It took a little away from the movie for me.Chiyo (Suzukha Ohgo) is a young girl who is sold, along with her sister, in Kyoto.  They are separated, and while her sister goes away, Chiyo is sold to an okiya (house for geishas) and is apprenticed as a Geisha there.  However, between trouble she brings on herself by trying to run away, and the jealousy of resident Geisha Hatsumomo (Gong Li), life doesn't go the way its supposed to for Chiyo.  Thinking herself destined to become a maid with no future, Chiyo gives up all hope until she is encountered by a handsome man on the bridge who buys her a flavored ice.  This man, the Chairman (Ken Watanabe), is what inspires her to do everything she can to become a Geisha.Years pass and Chiyo is finally given her chance when the famous Geisha Mameha (Michelle Yeoh) takes her under her wing and teaches her the art of the Geisha.  She debuts as Sayuri (Zhang Ziyi) and quickly earns her way to fame.  She faces some opposition from Hatsumomo and can never fully realize her dream of being with the Chairman as too many things get in the way.  She has her duty as a Geisha, then comes the War, and after the war she has to struggle to reearn her place in the world of Geisha.There are many other actors in this film of course but they play more minor roles compared to the ones already listed.  There is the vivacious Pumpkin (Youki Kudoh) who is first a friend and later a rival.  Nobi (Koji Yakusho) a stern man with no love of Geisha except for Sayuri.  Mother (Kaori Momoi) who runs the okiya and is a stern mistress and many others.  Most of them were well played although after reading the book, it seemed that Sayuri wasn't given as much personality in this film.  Mameha was played excellently as was the Chairman.The film itself was beautiful and the music authentic.  These two were paired throughout the film to make the art of the geisha and its no surprise that books have been made with photos from the film.  Everything, the costuming, make-up, and scenes were exquisitely done.  It was truly a pleasure for the eyes to watch.While somewhat disappointed with the film after reading the book it was still a masterpiece to watch and because not all read the book I will rate the film on its merit as a film alone; which is five stars.  This is definitely a movie to see.Review by M. Reynard 2010

reviewText: The movie begins with young Chiyo being sold of by her poor parents because they cannot support her.  She gets sent into a geisha house to live as a servant to geishas, who were basically high class prostitutes for their age. She accomplishes this, only to lose many things in turn, such as her old friends, her family, and most importantly, her sense of self-worth and self-respect.  Later, a world war upsets everything and things begin anew.  At the end, she encounters again the Chairman, and they finally reveal their hearts and histories to each other.  This movie is a potpourri of sadness, melancholy, drama, frustration, tragedy and only the occasionally happy moment.  The characters all have one of two flaws; either they are too innocent to keep away from evil, or too evil to leave the innocent alone.  Even the setting is depressing; overcrowded cities, poor countrysides, and of course, a male-dominated society with no sense of justice but a burdensome sense of honor.  All in all, a sad story meant for rainy days.

reviewText: I read the novel this film is based on and loved it, so I was looking forward to the movie when it was released. I was pleased to see that the movie followed the book very closely. The film was absolutely beautiful, with arresting shots of the geisha as they went about their daily tasks and beautiful pans of the gorgeous faces of the actresses. There were also a few nice shots of (what was supposed to be) the Japanese countryside.The film follws Chiyo (Sayuri), a young girl from the country who grows to become one of the most celebrated geisha in pre-war Japan. I know that there was a big stink when the film came out that some of the actresses cast were Chinese, rather than Japanese, but I say phooey on that. You cast an actor to play a role. I've seen plenty of straight actors turn in wonderfully nuanced performances of gay characters. I've seen plenty of older actors play roles that were younger than they were, and vice versa. So what? The director's job is to find the right actor for the role, and that actor may or may not be the exact nationality referred to in the script. The point is, does this performer tell the story?And the performers in Memoirs of a Geisha definitely do. Ziyi Zhang (Chiyo/Sayuri), Li Gong (Hatsumomo), and Michelle Yeoh (Mameha) all give their characters a wonderful depth and subtext, and I really enjoyed them. I know that some critics also huffed about the movie being Westernized, with the actors all speaking English, etc. Wha . . . ? The movie is based on a book written by Arthur Golden, a middle-aged white guy from Tennessee. How can you get more Western than that? Anyway, I personally found the film to be a visual jewel with fabulous performances. I recommend it.

reviewText: After watching this movie, I was left with mixed emotions. Perhaps the biggest flaw in this movie is filming it in english. I mean, sure it appeals to a broader audience but it loses part of it's authenticity. And no, I'm not Japanese and I would have to read the subtitles too but I'm guessing it would've been so much better.That said, let's delve into the Japanese culture, or at least from my point of view. I have always perceived Japanese as an honorable nation, with discipline and moral values. They have always left an impression of hardworking and dilligent people as well. I have no qualms about the casting of Geisha, but I felt the story itself had so many shortcomings. I don't know if it was written this way by Arthur Holden, or somewhere in between adapting it to screenplay, things got sour. The concept of Geisha was intrigueing but as a whole, the story was disappointing only because it did not leave a huge impact on me. It was just OKAY.Thank goodness the acting made up for it's lacklustre screenplay. The who's who of Asian cinema is cast and it was a brilliant decision. Although the dialogue is mediocre and even corny at times (maybe because of their poor command in english), they are able to act out their feelings with unbelievable charisma and this took the whole movie to a higher emotional level. I have watched many of Zhang Ziyi's movies since her debut and she never fails to impress me. She was breath-taking in the movie and displays the perfect ammount of determination, grief, happiness to bring her character Sayuki to life. Being a Malaysian myself, Michelle Yeoh certainly does my home country proud by being her regal self, and commanding respect in every scene she's in. And as for Gong Li, she deserves at least an Oscar nomination for her role of Hatsumomo. You can see the effects of her tormented life, how she wants more than what she has. You feel angry but at the same time, your heart goes out to her. Wonderful performance! Ken Watanabe was a bit miscast as Chairman, probably because I've gotten used to his kick-a$$ roles in movies like The Last Samurai and Batman Begins that seeing him here channeling romance and poetry was a little too much for me.The cinematography was also brilliant, with so much color and music that it breathed some life to the movie. It was definitely an attack on your sensors (in a good way). The direction was alrite, nothing outstanding I would say but Rob Marshall does pull off quite a lot of "money" shots here especially his take of Japanese traditions like swirling kimonos, sumo wrestling, those wooden houses and the "oh-so-amazing" geisha dances.But in the end, what would've made this good movie truely great is a better screenplay, but that's life, we can't get everything we hoped for can we?

reviewText: I read the book when it first came out, and wasn't terribly impressed by it.  I didn't see the movie at first, because it didn't seem to get the greatest reviews and the book had left me cold.  Then I watched it on cable, and was impressed enough to buy it. What impressed me wasn't just that the film is visually stunning, though it is.  Nor is the storyline itself so compelling at first glance. Not only was it pretty uninspiring as love stories go, but I wasn't too impressed with the "cinder" part of this cinderella tale -- young Chiyo actually got an amazing break, in that as an unwanted orphan sold into slavery, she got sold in a pretty good place for her sex and the times -- a place where she would get an expensive education, taught to read and write, learn a profession whereby she'd never even "have to pour herself a glass of sake because her maids do all that", etc.  In fact, Chiyo's initial whining and running away I thought was pretty uncharacteristic of what a girl in her position would do, given the realities -- the supposedly dumbwitted Pumpkin was far more savvy and realistic.  It's amazing to me all the reviewers who seem to miss that this is not a tale of a girl in the U.S. in the 21st century.  That being trained as a geisha and given the chance to inherit a valuable geisha house and adopted as a daughter and heir was pretty amazing luck for young Chiyo, if she could have appreciated it -- given she could have landed in far, far worse places from where she came.I spent a lot of the movie wondering about why the narrator seemed to whine so much about Chiyo's unlucky fate - it didn't seem realistic.  But what finally impressed me was the ending, where the narrator, who at times seemed to be over the top in her narration of a pretty basic story (mine is a story that should never be told) finally ended on a very realistic note.  I disagree that she just finally learned of "kindness, where there had been so much unkindness".  The Chairman, Mameha, Auntie, Pumpkin and even "Mother" were kind to her in their own ways.  But I like the fact that this film, perhaps one of the first that I can recall, apart from perhaps the "Handmaid's Tale" talked about how a woman sometimes has to make her happiness out of a glass half full. For an American movie, and a supposed "cinderella" romance, that was an amazing leap.  This was a Cinderella tale where Cinderella doesn't really get the prince.  She's not a fairy tale princess: as she says, she's  "not an "empress, nor a queen".  Finally and at the end, she makes no apologies for what she is, and for making her happiness out of what she can.  As she says, hers are memoirs of another kind. Whatever you think of the life of a geisha, (and some reviewers have perhaps deservedly panned the glorification of prostitution etc.) there is the fact that this was a different culture.  Chiyo, who seemed to rail against her fate with almost 21st century female expectations does an abrupt about face at the end. While disconcerting, what I found valuable and in some ways unique is that we don't see too many movies that hold out the illusion of a fairy tale ending and then unapologetically illustrate the half measures that women sometimes have to settle for, and find happiness with.  That I found interesting, even intriging. I'm not sure how well it hangs together as a movie or a book. It seems inconsistent to say the least. But I liked that she finally recognized it, and that the author and film didn't try to sell us the pretense of a real fairy tale ending where none existed.  She made her happiness where she could.  While not acceptable in this day and age, it was for her and I can only applaud that she could find her glass half full and not apologize for it.That said, I wish more time had been spent on the two girls, Chiyo and Pumpkin and their training, and lives.  The extras in this DVD go into that a little more and I found that very interesting.  I also went back after watching the movie and read the book again, and this was one of those rare times when I thought the movie as good or better than the book, and surprisingly faithful to the book.  I ended up purchasing the DVD two disk set, and highly recommend that and the book too.

reviewText: Oh dear.  Where to begin?  I watched the movie, all of the DVD extras on Disk 2, I read the opposing Amazon reviews, and also the original Arthur Golden book.  Since every like/dislike under the sun seem already to have been voiced here, I will stay away from repeating and becoming a statistic.  Before I go on, let me just say Memoirs of A Geisha pales in comparison to Hideo Gosha's 1983 film "The Geisha." The superb acting, combined with the authentic Japanese-ness and the beautifully photographed "The Geisha" puts that film in a league of its own.Three things you should know before you begin criticizing this movie.  1) The creators repeated several times in the DVD Extra Disk 2 that their movie is an impression, not a documentary.  2)This is an American movie made in Hollywood.  3) This is a movie based on a book written by a Caucasian writer based on his interviews with a geishas, one of which was Iwasaki Mineko, who went on to write her own account called A Life (because she felt Golden had twisted the real story too much).Ok. Item 1.  I found the DVD Disk 2 more entertaining than the movie itself, because it put the movie next to historical archives.  It was the creators' way, I felt, of giving the actual historical facts some airtime.  Watching DVD Disk 2 will help straighten out many of the arguments presented here in the Amazon reviews.  The creators of MOAG did consult Liza Dalby, an author herself of several books on Geishas and Japanese kimonos.  So if they wanted to, they could have devoted a large percentage of their resources towards getting the historical details fairly accurate.  However, the creators stressed several times that MOAG was an impression, not a documentary.  This impressionistic license means that the architecture, the kimonos, the Geisha life, dance, routine, hair, makeup are all based loosely on the actual facts.  The set designer (a Hollywood set designer) went to Japan for a few weeks and distilled a little bit from one building, and some more from another, and threw it all together in a (con)fusion of anachronistic and cross-cultural impressionistic town sitting in the backlot of a California town.  The costume maker, another non-Japanese who does not specialize in kimonos, did some research and started churning out a kimono every few weeks (where the real one takes a year and cost what an average Japanese man might make working full time for a year).  Rob Marshall, the director of Chicago (and dancer/choreographer by profession) jazzes up the Geisha dance routine, requests that his version of the Geisha is presented as "supermodels of their day."  The silhouette of MOAG's geishas are almost wasp-waisted, where the actual Geishas of that time emphasized cylindrical form in their kimono profile.Japanophiles and Japanese people will undoubtedly scream murder, and they have the right to.  However, if you keep in mind that MOAG is the product of the Western imagination, you will be able to watch the movie as entertainment.  It would have been nice if they got the details spot on, but I doubt it will make the mainstream audience love it more.Item 2. This is an American movie made in Hollywood, produced by Steven Spielberg.  People who have watched Wim Wenders's documentary Room 666 (where famous directors were asked about the future of cinema) will remember a long list of non-American directors carrying on about technology, craft, and the art of moviemaking, only to be followed by Spielberg, who sounded like an accountant whose primary concern was the bottom line.  He talked about financing, funds, box office returns, and then he talked some more about money.  Nothing wrong with that, but it explains the decisions they made for MOAG.  You could make a movie with authentic Japanese actors speaking Japanese, with Shakuhachi, koto, and shamisen laden soundtrack, and get consultation from everyone from the Learning Channel to the History Channel.  But on opening night, the cinema will have only a handful of seats occupied by stuffy academics and bookworms.  Instead, take John Williams's music, throw in Itzhak Perlman, Yo-Yo Ma, then use all the biggest recognizable Asian actors in America, make it pretty, and pace it for American consumption.  What do you get?  Academy awards, money in the bank, and most importantly, thousands of people with newly whetted appetites who want to learn more about Japanese culture.  The ones who have the conscientiousness to research further, will eventually obtain the accurate details anyway.I'm not saying I understand this approach, but I do understand that this is an American movie made for American consumption.Item 3. This movie is based on a book written by a Caucasian writer.  Epistemologically speaking, this movie is already three steps removed from fact, if you count Mineko's self-editing in re-telling her story.  There's also the case of Mineko who did not speak English as a first language, and Golden who did not speak Japanese as a first language.  There's a wide chasm between transmission and perception even by the time the story reaches book form.  Art is not always obligated to truth.  And the history of art has always been driven by what each interpreted work (in each artist's reiteration of the fashionable themes of his or her day) revealed about the interpreter and not the interpreted.  If Marshall is a choreographer, then it is only logical that he speaks in a medium he is most familiar with, dance.Though quality is not being questioned here, I am reminded of digital photography's golden rule: if you don't begin with the best original picture, subsequent edits can only go downhill from there.  Both Golden and Rob Marshall never pretended they know what goes on in the pure Japanese consciousness when they dispatch their respective versions of MOAG.  What I know of Japanese consciousness comes from zen koans, kimonos, the art of Ike no Taiga and Tawaraya Sotatsu, but I can tell you Memoirs of a Geisha has very little evidence of it.With all that said, I thought the movie was watchable, and it was not slow.  People who complained about Zhang Ziyi's acting may want to be reminded of the Japanese classical tradition of Noh, where masks are worn during the performance, and facial expressions hidden.  Combined this with the Japanese tendency to subtlety and hidden connotations, and you begin to realize maybe restraint was an intention, and expecting her to act like Lindsay Lohan may be slightly ethnocentric.  Michelle Yeoh does a good job being the stately mentor to Sayuri, but her curiously orange hair did raise my eyebrows.  I think the opening of the movie left out an important part of the book.  We don't really know the reasons why Tanaka sold the two little girls to the okiya.  In the book, we know that their parents were very poor and they lived in a country fishing village.  The father was barely making ends meet, and the mother was dying.  It could be proposed that the parents agreed to their girls being sold off because that was, by comparison, a better life than that which they could barely offer.  If you begin on this premise, then it gives you a very different perception of what it meant to be a geisha, even though geishas are correctly depicted as people who did not have a choice.The movie is paced better than the book, and it made a story (that is already geared for public consumption) move right along.  However, there were dozens of times where I found myself saying "gosh, if I hadn't read the book, I could not make the leap from the previous scene to this one."  For example, we see Hatsumomo finding Sayuri's face on a poster.  All that is left out includes the detail that Mameha's meteoric rise to fame came from her appearance on a poster for a celebrated annual festival.  In the book, Mameha choreographed a very Japanese "dance" where Sayuri goes to the poster artist's disheveled studio and hangs out until the "suggestion" is "introduced" to him that he has a brilliant idea of using Sayuri for a model.  These low-key transactions are what reminds me of traditional Asian (and Japanese) etiquette.For the purpose of the movie though, I guess it was enough to tell what it needed to tell.So if you can suspend your allegiance to factual and historical details for two hours, then it's entertainment in the form we recognize it to be.  Suzuka Ohgo as the young Chiyo is absolutely adorable, and the movie is a good (but light) exposure for some of the biggest Chinese actresses working today.  Gong Li's Hatsumomo translates onscreen better than it did in the novel, as her character, like Golden's story, is really about the passing of time. Watch the dvd extra on Disk 2 to round up your Hollywood intro to Geishas.  If you want to go deeper and enter the actual Japanese world of storytelling, one can start with Mizoguchi, Kurosawa, and Ozu.  There is also a whole pantheon of Japanese films that never make it to the US.  Film lovers owe it to themselves to explore the birthplace of Clint Eastwood westerns, Star Wars, and some of Jacques Rivette's most memorable masterpieces.
summary: A Piece of Art, Not a Documentary

reviewText: "Water can carve its way even through stone.And when trapped, water makes a new path"It was with great expectation that I watched Memoirs of a Geisha. reviewText: 'Memoirs of a Geisha' is one of my favourite novels of all time. I was very worried about this movie, I have to say. I was expecting some horribly westernised and dumbed-down version of the text, but I have to say, I was very pleased with the end result. Okay, so it's not as deep or as evocative as the novel, and yes, in places the Spielbergisms (he was, after all, a Producer) are garish and out-of-place, but overall, the movie remains very faithful to the feel of the book, and, for a nice change, has a beautifully sympathetic screenplay by Robin Swicord, and Rob Marshall's direction is superlative.Casting is actually fabulous; Ken Wanatabe as Chairman Iwamura Ken is perfect - maybe a little younger at the film's end than I was expecting, but he's a great actor anyway, and in what I believe is his first romantic lead in a western picture, turns in a very convincing performance. Gong-Li is a perfect, perfect Hatsumomo - it's great to see one of my favourite literary characters of all time brought so fluently and vibrantly alive. Zhang Ziyi is an inexperienced actress and doesn't perhaps bring as much depth to the character of Sayuri as one would have hoped, but for the tone of the movie, she's very well-paced. Michelle Yeoh, as always, does a great job playing Michelle Yeoh. But since the character of Mameha is a benevolent mother-figure anyway, she's also quite convincing.The voiceovers from older Sayuri are fantastic, rather than feeling like a device to keep the movie's running time down, they actually serve to deepen the sense of autobiography that the really quite brilliant screenplay tries to put across. Not much of it is from Golden's original text, but happily, the new dialogue and expressions are, by and large, sympathetic and, more importantly, well-written. Since the voice of Sayuri the elder was such an important tool in the novel, it's hugely gratifying to see that Swicord's writing understands and promotes this in the translation to the big screen. The script also uses common Japanese terms and phrases for added effect - and this works very well.Direction is fabulous, Rob Marshall proves here that he can do historical romances every bit as well as he does glossy musicals and comedies. The scenes where Baron Matsunaga attempts to seduce Sayuri, or Chiyo's arrival at the Okiya, are shot with such an obvious understanding of what Golden's original text was saying, that you can't help but feel Marshall is trying - and succeeding- to be as respectful as possible to the elements that made the novel great.It's not all good news, however, and there are several things in the movie, when one judges it as a movie in its own right, that don't ring true. The first and most important of these is the obvious difficulty the Japanese actresses playing the roles of Mother, Auntie and the younger Chiyo and Pumpkin have with delivering their English lines. Or should that be `engurrish rines' ? Since the lead cast members don't have this trouble, it creates a sense of discord between the excellent main body of the movie and what must be said is a somewhat less-than-convincing beginning. Another complaint is the obvious attempt to `westernise' the story to make it more accessible for western audiences - various elements such as Sayuri's fight with Hatsumomo or Mameha's relationship with her Danna are overstated and glaringly obvious, and lack the subtlety of the rest of the movie. Which makes no sense, really, when you consider that the original novel was by an American, and for a primarily English-speaking audience.Still, `Memoirs' is a great movie; respectful of, if not totally faithful to, the wundernovel that spawned it, I came away from it with the same sense of awe and delightedness that I did when I closed the book. As an adaptation, it works beautifully, and as a movie in its own right, it's extremely well-crafted and very entertaining.
summary: Excellent adaptation, and an excellent movie.

reviewText: "Memoirs of a Geisha" is a love story that remains tedious and distant from being an epic love story on scale with Casabalanca, Dr. Zhivago, or even Titanic...The story follows one particular Japanese peasant girl whose father sends her and her sister to a famous geisha house... Her less attractive sister is sent away to a house of prostitution, and Chiyo is given domestic tasks until the time when she can be trained to be a geisha....Naturally, the main appeal of the film is the glimpse into the true nature of the geisha... How a geisha becomes a pinnacle of elegance and class, a master of entertainment and a royal agent of many gentle graces, how she sells her skills and not her body, how she can be the keeper of traditional arts, and how she can stop a man in his tracks with only one look... Yet the film postulates that a geisha's ultimate goal is her debut as a flamboyant dancer, sell her virginity, and pride herself on being well paid for it...The film's photography is outstanding, the music score is inventive, the editing is concise and timed perfectly, and Ziyi Zhang overflows with sensitivity, delicacy, and sensuality...Zhang has "the sea in her eyes." She is fascinating as the lovely heroine, the tender mood of every man, the quality of being graceful, the gentlemen's companion enclosed by an ever-changing Japan towards the start of World War II... reviewText: **1/2If you like your historical fiction visually opulent, dramatically inert and just a wee bit on the stuffy side, then "Memoirs of a Geisha" is the movie for you.Based on the best-selling novel by Arthur Golden, "Memoirs of a Geisha" tells of a small girl who is sold into virtual slavery, trained to pleasure men as a mincing, tea-pouring geisha.  The movie shows us the inner workings of this strange and exotic world - the rules, the rituals, the internecine conflicts and the ultimate dehumanization of the women therein.  Yet, it does so in such a cliched, prettified way that the sharpness of the message winds up getting blunted, smoothed over, and ultimately contradicted in the process.Dion Beebe's Oscar-winning cinematography (though actually not as impressive as the work in either "Brokeback Mountain" or "The New World," which were also nominated), along with the ravishing costumes and sets, does indeed create a lovely tableau of 1940's Japan, but often at the expense of the theme, which is to show us the UGLINESS not the beauty of that world.The tale is largely slow-paced and languid, with the first section, in particular, playing a bit like an Oriental version of a Charles Dickens melodrama.  The acting is decent for the most part, but eventually everything - the storyline, the message and the performances - wind up getting buried under the trappings.

I perform Japanese dance since 2000 and am unable to dance solo; learning evocative steps as an adult dancer-actor on platform okobo must be athletically demanding. Michelle Yeoh (ethnic Chinese Malaysian) is a martial arts master who studied classical ballet in London. Ziyi Zhang (Chinese) is a classical dancer and martial arts practitioner as well. The actors collaborated in Oscar best filmCrouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. Ziyi Zhang reveals athletic prowess in martial arts inHouse of Flying Daggersas well.Director Marshall needed graceful athletically limber dancer-actors capable of absorbing 10 years of geisha training in shamisen, fan, kimono, fish-tail gait, sitting, serving tea and dance in a 6 week rehearsal prior to filming. All actors, Malaysian, Chinese, Thai, Japanese, Vietnamese, etc. memorized lines in phonetic English, were only able to acquire dignified comportment, grace, dance, etc. in the restricted rehearsal time due to prior mastery of skills as linguists, actors, and dancers.If one compares Memoirs to Japanese classic DVD Samurai Rebellion directed by Masaki Kobayashi, starring Toshiro Mifune, parallels are evident: emotions rigidly restrained even in the face of rape, societal demands for female acceptance and discretion in abysmal circumstances, subtle sadness and overt tension in public face vs. private agony and despair.At rehearsal Japanese dancers are voluble, laughing with ribald jokes (cannot pronounce letter "l" so instead of using word clap, say kachung) But during performance, only aesthetically pleasing demeanor appears. Japanese dance is slowly repetitive, like watching grass grow: sedate emotionally placid on the surface, intense with meaning below if well understood. The same disconnect occurs between public and private life of 1920s geisha, appropriately portrayed onscreen: rigidly mannered in public, feisty volatility in private, always with an undercurrent of melancholy. Even sunlight in Japan postures in a minor key.Geisha Mineko Iwasaki's autobiography Geisha of Gion: The Memoir of Mineko Iwasaki describes a visually lush, emotionally barren life; as the most celebrated geisha of all time, she was tortured by a real life rival like Hatsumomo (Gong Li) and retired from geisha life. The oldest working geisha is 94.Nobu is played by Koji Yakusho star of the original JapaneseShall We Dance?His confrontation with Sayuri when he believes she is arranging a liaison with another man is passionate and humiliating: unrequited love as physical pain.The art of geisha demands so much rehearsal, preparation, performance, entertainment work time there is no space for romance, marriage, family. Geisha drink alcohol to entertain. If geisha marries, she abandons geisha life.Sayuri's water theme played by Yo Yo Ma on cello, and Chairman's theme played by Itzak Perlman on violin are tributes to John Williams' composition.Compare Memoirs to the British restraint ofPersuasionwith Amanda Root and Ceiran Hinds, the contained emotion ofJane Eyre (BBC, 1983)with Timothy Dalton and Zelah Clark as a fiery child who learns to withhold emotions after years of abuse (not unlike the life of geisha), and the misdirection wrought by hidden passion inPride and Prejudice - The Special Edition (A&E;, 1996)with Colin Firth. Superficial containment may cloak longing and suffering.Memoirs has humor: 15 year old Sayuri opens the door to the famous geisha Mameha sneaking a look over her shoulder, Sayuri's hair is ratted and waxed, she then tries to sleep on a wooden head rest omaku to protect the styling (maiko have their own hair dressed, later when they are full geisha they wear wigs), Sayuri's leg is cut by Mameha, her stage fright prior to her debut, Sayuri slips off her geta then causes a boy to fall from his bike with a mere glance.See alsoDeparturesabout healing and forgiveness, James Clavell's Shogun 15hour 5 disc TV miniseries about 1500s Shogunate, The Last Samurai (Two-Disc Special Edition) about 1800s transition, House of Flying Daggers with Ziyi Zhang as a blind dancer.

reviewText: Rob Marshall`s "Memoirs Of A Geisha" doesn't have an ounce of gray in it. There's black, and white, bold, blood red, deep aqua blue and sunlight river gold. But no subtlety, no nuance. Wall-to-wall melodrama, it opens on a stormy night and closes on a blooming lagoon. It's a prestige picture succeeding in escapism and the enjoyment of watching catty, beautiful women prance around in thousand-dollar costumes.Geisha houses were popular in Japan for centuries through the 1950s; they still operate, I suppose, in their own way as escort services, though girls are no longer sold into the profession in elementary school and then trained for ten years before their virginity is sold to the highest-bidding client. It's formal prostitution, though Marshall and Co. would like us to think the long, long (long) smoldering affair between Sayuri (Ziyi Zhang) and "The Chairman" (Ken Watanabe) is a kind of forbidden love.For years it doesn't seem Sayuri, born with sky blue eyes, will be anything more than janitor of her house, so manipulated she is by the house's best-earning geisha Hatsumomo (GongLi, excellent) a jealous vamp skilled in flirt and theft. Hatsumomo sizes up her much-younger housemate and decides Sayuri's friend, the clumsy Pumpkin (Youki Kudoh) will be easier to control.It isn't until a classier geisha named Mameha (Michelle Yeoh) recognizes Sayuri's beauty and potential talent that Sayuri is allowed to go to school, learn the art of sexual insinuation and eventually debut in a light-and-sound performance suitable for a high-class strip joint.  Through these formative years she must duel with Hatsumomo until the inevitable showdown, when House Mother (Kaori Momoi) must choose heir house heir and the vamp discovers the wunderkind's crush on The Chairman, who once treated Sayuri to a sno-cone.Does it sound trite? Oh, it's a soap opera.  But "Memoirs Of A Geisha" with its top-shelf production values, presents one visual flourish after another. Zhang and Yeoh, sensing larger access to Hollywood, deliver sincere performances. And there's a great villain in Gong Li, who at 40 must play a 22-year-old - and sneers and snorts her way to stealing the movie.But Hatsumomo exits the movie two-thirds of the way through and the movie must shift to Sayuri's trials through the end of World War II, the destruction of Japan, and eventual rebuilding, when the Chairman requests her service for a few American generals to help secure an industrial contract. reviewText: Memoirs of a Geisha is visually beautiful, the cinematography masterful.  It is also expertly performed.  Each actor brings a lot of credibility and emotion to his/her role.  The story is intriguing but a bit slow to develop.  The emotional highs and lows, the backstabbing, petty jealousies, maneuvering, and (small group) politicking will hold your interest, but this is not an edge-of-your-seat thriller by any stretch.  It is simply a drama (which happens to be much better than the typical Hollywood drama.)At its core, Memoirs is a love story in an exotic setting.  Love and loyalty are presented in very conventional ways.  Nothing about this film will challenge you to question why this character loves that one or whether one character's loyalty to another is justified.  Though a love story, it's not necessarily a "chick flick."  Certainly, love triumphs in the end, the protagonist's dreams become real, and she lives happily ever after.  But, this movie is not drenched with the type of sentimentality that makes American male moviegoers squirm and wish they were anywhere else but watching the movie (at least, perhaps, not until the very end.)  The woman does not win at her lover's expense.  He does not sell his soul, give up his life, to woo her.As good as it is, Memoirs has one significant drawback: it's unoriginal.  It is little more than Cinderella set in war-time Japan.  Cinderella's not a princess but a Geisha.  Prince Charming is a captain of post-war Japanese industry, a close friend to one of the richest men in Japan.  The fairy godmother is another Geisha who takes Chiyo under her wing.  Chiyo promises in the beginning of the film that hers is a tragic tale that should never be lived.  Her warning rings hollow at the end of this rags-to-riches story in which she lands the man of her dreams, her reason for being.  A more interesting (and emotionally challenging) ending might have been the one hinted at just before the close of the film, before the "twist ending" that everyone knows is coming.RATING NOTE:  It deserves 5 stars for the acting and cinematography but only about 2 TO 3 stars for the rest of the story.  I give it 4 stars even though I think 3.5 stars would be a more accurate rating.

reviewText: Readers of Arthur Golden's book would have sympathised with this movie's producers for the fundamental challenge they must have faced with this adaptation: Frequently confronted with the temptation of an investment of judgement in the subject it depicted, it had to steer a course of cultural ambivalence or agnosticism, or, if some manner of an assessment was unavoidable, deal only with aspects that were indubitable and stark for the audience to discern on its own. That its screenplay manages this with some poise, which for the most part is tentative instead of cautious, is just about the only bit of credit it can claim, for in the hands of a lesser cast and director, `Memoirs of a Geisha' could not have been carried by the script alone.For the greater part of this celluloid treatment, before its affecting denouement (and, to a substantial extent, its saving grace), nothing feels compelling. Relationships are for a large part thin and unconvincing. Friendships are not weakly developed, but rivalries and manipulation, usually being the easier to describe, are what mainly characterise the character dynamics. That the young character Chiyo is given a substantial viewing in the beginning, eschewing the domination of the headline stars, is admirable, demonstrating patience in building an emotional foundation to her motivations, but which, eventually with the departure of Suzuka Ohgo, who plays her comfortably, we find doesn't exist strongly enough for the rest of the movie to ride upon. Ken Watanabe's first appearance is a welcome warm presence, but again underwritten, and thus one never sees, until later, how the young to-be meiko could be driven to begin taking resolute steps in her life, every one of which supposedly bringing her closer to him. The script, in presenting Chiyo's cruel childhood, conveniently throws in generic and vague descriptors such as `empty' and `nothing', which do, well, nothing more than refer denotatively to her destitute existence, which anyone would be able to recognise, instead of ploughing into the characteristics of that emptiness: How she had to grow up too quickly, how she became effaced before she knew personality, how she had nothing to hope for or aspire to, nothing laid before her and no one to connect with. Zhang Ziyi's first appearance almost instinctively forces a reflection on her character's preceding experiences on the part of the audience, and it's quite remarkable how simplistic those experiences can come across: In a `tiny little world of women' from the `floating world', aside from the ruthlessness of the people around her and a man she comes attached to, what exactly has she learnt, and how does it steel her for the future?The writing fares better after the movie's first third, when it picks up on some of the subtleties of what Chiyo goes through. Before we see her grown up, the head of the okiya, importantly, tells her, `We are all the family you have now.' That statement encapsulates an examination of the ties she has had with people up to that point and will have beyond, and is a significant mark of the tragedy of her experience: Parents who sold her, a friendship turned acrimonious (with some charming acting from Youki Kudoh), a mentor who plays her like a pawn, and whose apparent concern and kindness are thereby made dubious (Michelle Yeoh, who shows a natural ease with her character), employers who, while seemingly wanting the best for her, have a questionable idea of what that entails, and a poisonous nemesis whom she fears, hates and sympathises with (Gong Li, ever masterful with a ferocious, wine-dark elegance). The writing also picks up on the consequence of the changes in Chiyo's name, and every shift - from Chiyo to Sayuri and then Nitta Sayuri - marks a notable development in the plot and her character. Frequently, we're reminded of how she's chosen to define herself - by becoming an accomplished geisha - and that adds to the bitter-sweetness of the ending, when one wonders whether she's truly found herself, if ever she has at all, and if she ever thought the white painted mask of the geisha would someday come off, in spite of everything that has compelled her to be bound to that identity, if it can be called one.But the movie owes much to a well-chosen cast that taps easily into the emotional wells of their characters, which the shallow writing belies. When Zhang Ziyi first emerges, one sees nothing of her Golden Globe nomination, but in considering her performance in its entirety, her character's transition, from girlish modesty to suspicious but confident tactician, to worldly wise and despairing woman who learns to own herself, is believable. Ken Watanabe commands the screen by simply being on it, and like Yeoh, in the best sense, rarely seems to be acting. The latter performs quite a feat of understatement, rendering Mameha a conceivable, human character, strong, pragmatic and caring in her own way, however misguided, and holding her own very respectably against Zhang's presence as the leading lady while allowing her the space to make her mark as the main actress. Kaori Momoi and Tsai Chin lift their roles from stereotypical Asian caricatures, the former filling the shoes of a benumbed and callous Mother, who always seems vaguely amused by the wretchedness of their circumstances, the latter an affectionate Auntie for whom it visibly hurts to uphold the ways of the okiya with Chiyo. The characters of Nobu and the Baron could almost be replicas of each other, but it's Koji Yakusho and Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa who make them distinct, the former a scarred and sad man, the latter a forceful and domineering one who expects to get what he wants. In the spirit of saving the best for last, Gong Li strikes a formidable and venomous figure. Every step of the way we are reminded of a beautiful woman ruined and degraded by her ways, her desires and her jealousies on her chosen path in life. Gong Li is vigorous in her acting, and be it in expressing disdain, anger, pride and wilfulness even in loss, or an intimidating quality, Hatsumomo becomes a full-blooded character, a scarlet whirlwind of vindictiveness and turmoil to be wary of lest she sweeps you off your feet with cunning or seduction. This reviewer would like to see her receive a Best Supporting Actress nomination at the Oscars, which, even if she doesn't win for, would provide adequate recognition of her delectable performance here.At the least, where `Memoirs' isn't an emotional experience, it is very much a sensory one. John Williams serves up a fine score with post-modern touches, not so much thematically memorable, unlike most of his scores, as it does play like a seamless, atmospheric suite that puts it more in line with what he did for `A.I.'. The elemental quality in his music is most vital, and Sayuri's Theme perfectly displays a subliminal mind to water (ironically, it's where the overt Japanese touches don't come in and the score attains something ungraspable, but undeniable, that lies somewhere between experiential immersion and the mind of a little girl that Williams is at his best). Rob Marshall displays his eye for beauty here more so than he did in `Chicago', and the images captured, while teetering on the brink of psychedelic monotony after a while, are often ravishing to behold. Where he is noticeably attuned to the nuances of expression, Marshall doesn't hesitate to linger on the face of a character to show her changes in emotion or the turmoil that a skin-deep smile or bewitching gaze tries to conceal. When Hatsumomo is discovered with Koichi, for instance, we see her go from vengefulness, to bitterness, then, with a quick downward teary glare, the sting of separation as Mother declares that the gates be shut. In the same scene, we see Chiyo, first looking up at her in fear, slowly tilt her head down, in silent lamentation of the sordidness that now characterises her world. When Zhang approaches Yeoh later in the movie for aid in becoming a geisha once again, we see the torn smile on Zhang's face as Yeoh presents an old kimono: The hope of success in doing something that will gain her the Chairman's affections, rekindled by Yeoh's helpfulness, the doubt and fear of returning to her early ways, and a part of her that, beyond questioning, loathes the notion of doing so, all written in her strained and teary beam. The greatest moments in the movie that Marshall manages are those such as these, when you're allowed enough time with each character to engage them and find something worth caring about.The best things about the movie meet in its truly moving ending, when the Chairman professes his hidden love for Sayuri, borne for all the years she has tried to work her way to him. In the moment of that confession, Sayuri is forced to look back on everything with a renewed perspective - how so much of the unkindness in her life might have been averted, how she might have avoided shame, how some things didn't have to be endured - and her experiences painfully come full circle. Zhang's performance here - crying with restraint, trembling all over - precisely conveys the utter rush of conflicting and exasperated emotions coursing through her, how she might be angry with the Chairman for indirectly putting her through everything needlessly, even as she is drawn to him uncontrollably, her yearning much too powerful to suppress now that an opportunity has finally presented itself to be with him. Watanabe, both in guilt and compassion, warmly receives her being of inner tumult and soothes her, while tearfully realising what he might have been able to keep her from. The setting for their meeting is apt, bright, colourful and optimistic - a change from the lamp-lit streets where the `wives of nightfall' wandered - and the score reaches an understated climax. What's wonderful is that it all drives home the point that it isn't a perfect ending. In many ways, it's unsatisfactory for Sayuri, but the sensitivity with which this is shown affords a glimpse, before the movie ends, of everything that remains unresolved for her.This isn't a boring movie, but it verges on testing at times. Even in dealing with the fundamental cultural premise, one doesn't get a sense of an informed account with a sincere interest in looking at, what might strike many as, a strange way of life. A few awkward moments in the movie, such as where it deals less than delicately with `the eel that enters the cave', which turns out as an unintentionally comical and gratuitously indiscreet attempt at politeness, don't do anything to help. Thus, even with an awareness that the movie partially, consciously or otherwise, romanticises this aspect of Japanese culture, where holding oneself in dignity is either genuine and fierce self-respect or delusory posturing, it all comes off as a bit of polished - very polished - fluff.2 stars, then, for a story that stays up in the air somewhere in the floating world.
