reviewText: Bestselling books have a built in audience, making them very attractive to film producers. Often, when Hollywood adapts a popular bestseller to the screen, they are unable to capture the magic of the book.Such is the case with "Memoirs of a Geisha", the new film directed by Rob Marshall ("Chicago") based on the enormously popular book by Arthur Golden. Many, many, many people read and loved the book, which seems odd considering an American male wrote the book, a true testament to the writer's skill. He so successfully made the reader believe he was simply translating the life story of a real Geisha, we ate it up. He brilliantly evoked the time, place and feel of the period, giving us a glimpse of Japan just before the War. It was a great, interesting book."Memoirs of a Geisha" did not translate as well to the screen as the loyal fans of the book might have hoped. The film looks great, but it doesn't capture the life of Sayuri (Ziyi Zhang) as well, making her a living, breathing human being.Unable to care for their children, their parents sell Chiyo and her sister, Tanaka, to a Geisha house. Arriving at the house, the sisters are split up and Chiyo grudgingly begins to accept her new life as a housemaid for the domineering Mother. Soon, Hatsumomo (Gong Li, "Raise the Red Lantern", "Farewell, My Concubine"), the Geisha in the house, takes a disliking to Chiyo and proceeds to make her life hell. Soon, Chiyo is off to Geisha school, but events cause her to become an indentured servant within the house. One day, while out doing errands, she meets the Chairman (Ken Watanabe, "The Last Samurai"). Years later, Chiyo (Ziyi Zhang, "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon", "House of Flying Daggers", "Rush Hour 2") has grown up and Mameha (Michelle Yeoh, "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon", "Tomorrow Never Dies"), a leading Geisha, takes her under her wing to train her.There are two significant problems hindering the film. The first is Ziyi Zhang. She is certainly a beautiful woman, but her acting leaves something to be desired. Throughout, she has trouble with the emotions, the problems of the character, making her believable. She resembles a Geisha performing an interpretation of being a Geisha, robbing the character of lifelike feeling and emotion. Throughout, she seems to turn on the emotion she is meant to felt for that scene, as though the director said "Sad", so she feels sad. When the next scene begins, new emotion. These emotions don't appear to be gradual, or real, as she proceeds through the character's life.The other problem is the voice over narration bridges over gaps in the narration, rather than help transition through them. The voice over tells us what to feel rather than reinforces what we feel. Because of this, it feels obtrusive and jarring to suddenly hear something that we had no inkling ever happened.There are a couple of great, visual sequences. One of these shows Sayuri's training to become a Geisha over a very short period of time. The scene is very visual and breathtaking to watch. A series of short, visual shots of various aspects of her education are bridged by transitions following one object from the frame to the next. This sequence, which is very fast, begins to give the viewer a sense of the work and training involved.Michelle Yeoh does a great job as Mameha, the more experienced, kinder mentor Geisha. As she guides Sayuri, Chiyo's adopted Geisha name, through the process, we learn a lot about what their life was like. The traditions, their place in society, the goals they worked towards are all presented by the older mentor. As Yeoh moves gracefully through each scene, she becomes a benevolent judge to the protégé, guiding her, but not afraid to reprimand her for a mistake either. As a result, she guides us through their unusual world.Gong Li is also quite good as Hatsumomo, the Geisha who feels threatened by Chiyo and makes her life a living hell. Clearly, Hatsumomo doesn't entirely buy into the Geisha's world as she is courting a young man who could never afford the charms of a Geisha, but she is deathly afraid of losing any of her standing. As she comes to feel more threatened, she also lashes out more frequently, and in increasingly sadistic methods, tormenting the young Chiyo.Ken Watanabe plays the Chairman, the object of Sayuri's attentions. Throughout the film, forces conspire to keep them apart and he subtly reveals that this is tearing him apart as well.Director Rob Marshall certainly has a visual eye. In all of the scenes set before World War II, the landscapes are occasionally infused with bright, vivid colors. When a person of wealth or influence enters the scene, some bright color almost always accompanies them or is found by the camera. If the scene is set in a predominantly poor area or the people who live there are poor, the colors are washed out. This is a nice reinforcement of how class affected the daily life in Japan during this era.What he doesn't do as well is guide the actors through their performances. This is problematic when the actors are less experienced and need the expertise of an accomplished director. The director needs to coax a subtle, interesting performance out of the actors, and not allow them to simply turn the emotion on and off. Marshall has a keen eye for detail, but needs to develop his skill working with the actors.When the story moves into the phase after World War II, it became even less interesting for me. Anything Zhang Ziyi was able to build with her character was lost as she desperately attempts to become a Geisha once again, to help the Chairman get some American financing. We simply didn't spend enough time with Sayuri as a Geisha to believe that she is now the type of woman who can summon all of her reserves and training and return to a former life. And the reason behind this is, in our modern eyes, slightly creepy to begin with. The actress would have to work very hard to convince us that this is real, to allow us to get beyond the inherently creepy nature of the task. Ziyi can't pull it off and it becomes tedious as we wait for the inevitable conclusion."Memoirs of a Geisha" has a few moments that will please fans of the book. If you can catch a bargain matinee, you will probably not felt cheated.
summary: Cliffs Notes: Memoirs of a Geisha

reviewText: First of all, I must say that I am a Japanese who can point out many incorrect things about the descriptions of Japan in the early Showa Period (1930s-40s). But I won't do it because I am well aware that `Memoirs of a Geisha' is a fantasy, not a documentary. By now, I believe, most viewers know that the heroine Sayuri/Chiyo is played by Zhang Ziyi who is not Japanese, but Chinese, but let's not talk about it now. I know the film companies in Hollywood thought they need not only a talent but a `name,' and Zhang Ziyi certainly has both. But a bigger problem is still there, and that is the language, English. And you can still find the biggest problem, and that is the soap-opera-ish story that goes on and on.If I refer to the film (set in Japan) as `soap opera,' I would be justified because the story goes like this. Chiyo and her sister are `sold' to `okiya' where geishas live because their parents have no money. Chiyo grows up to be a beautiful geisha `Sayuri' herself after she decided to meet again a kind gentleman `The Chairman' (Ken Watanabe) and she says, she wants to `be his.' They do meet again, but there are so many obstacles, like bullying from and rivalry with the older geisha Hatsumomo (Gong Li). And there is a war. And there is a womanizing `Baron'. And there is ... Well, I haven't read the book of Arthur Golden, but I think that is not this melodramatic.And the film at one time tries to correct the wrong image about geisha, who is sometime regarded as a courtesan. At least, that's what I heard in the interview with Rob Marshall (`Chicago'). But some (including me) would say that the film is rather trying to reinforce that wrong image with the heroine who does not seem to resist to the idea about sleeping with the `highest bidder.' What does he really want to present with Sayuri after all?There are, however, some good points about the long and winding story and one-dimensional characters. The sisterly chemistry between Sayuri and Mameha (Michelle Yeoh) who takes young Sayuri under her wing gives some light and refreshing moments. Yeoh is always associated with action films (who once stole scenes from Jackie Chan in `Police Story 3') and showed a great martial arts fight with Zhan Ziyi in `Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.' But her acting here proves that she can not only punch and kick (and fly), but also act.Another merit of the film is its beautiful images by Dion Beebe (`Chicago') and costumes with many kimono clothes. The geishas' town `Hanamachi' (literally, `Flower Town'), possibly made Gion District, Kyoto in mind, looks Japanese enough, and Rob Marshal can take the credit of recreating the inside of the Japanese houses, including furniture and other things, near perfect. (But I'm a connoisseur, you know.) It can be said, to be fair, that they did researches. For example, the sumo champion of the film is played by the real ex-professional sumo wrestler Mainoumi, and the scene of the sumo bout is credible. (But, of course, as to other things, not everything is perfect, but as I promised, I won't complain.)Though the loud music of John Williams comes with too much of Oriental taste, the solo part of Yo-Yo Ma and Itzhak Pearlman reminds you of the fact that good music is always good, no matter what instrument you might use.But the film has many flaws, and they are all big ones. The greatest problem is, as I said, its language. Except for the opening (where you can see Mako briefly), the characters all speak in English. In this kind of film, you must ignore the accents of the players, but in `Memoirs of a Geisha' it is too obvious that the actors find it too much to speak not in their languages, and consequently the acting looks too restrained. Koji Yakusho (original `Shall We Dance') is an excellent actor, and so is Zhang Ziyi, but here they are often seen struggling to speak the dialogues which themselves are not very memorable. Ken Watanabe fares better, and so do Yuki Kudo and Michelle Yeoh, but in the case of Gong Li the language is doing great harm to her otherwise strong (but slightly over-) acting. But the biggest disaster is the fact that the use of English deprived the ritualistic universe of geisha of its myth and mystery. Geisha-san must speak (and act) with elegance. The geisha of this film certainly acts elegantly, but speaks rather horribly.[ZHANG ZIYI and GONG LI] Now I said what I want to say, except this. Zhang Ziyi is not bad, and probably she will be nominated in the award races this winter (though her acting is most impressive during the non-verbal sequences). Anyway, it is a pity (and irony perhaps) that though Zhang Ziyi may be the most famous face in this film, `Memoirs' is also the debut film in Hollywood for the respected actress Gong Li (The end credit of the film may be misleading.) As many film fans know, she has shown great acting in many of Chinese masterpieces such as `A Terracotta Warrior' and `Raise the Red Lantern,' and I can say you have not seen the real Gong Li unless you see these past films of her. She is much better actress than is suggested by the supporting role of this film.So, is `Memoirs of a Geisha' good? It surely looks beautiful, but please don't expect to see the real universe of geisha, or Japan and its culture. As I said before, it is all fantasy. But probably you've already known that too.(Oh, and here's trivia. The film's title is changed to `Sayuri' in Japan probably because the distributors thought the word `geisha' might suggest a stereotyped image of Japan. Well, but I don't know.)
summary: Soap Opera in Kyoto: Beautiful Kimono Cannot Hide Its Hollow Content

reviewText: Gong Li has been the most internationally acclaimed Chinese actress along with Maggie Cheung in the '90s, with memorable roles in movies such as Farewell My Concubine, Raise the Red Lantern, and this year's 2046, she's proven to be a reigning Diva. I was rather surprised that she was willing to settle for a supporting role next to Zhang Ziyi, who gets nicknamed "Gong Li Jr." After viewing this film, I understand why she's perfect to be cast as the vindictive and catty Diva Geisha named Hatsumono. It was reported that Li was so impressive in this movie, that she was hired instantly for leads in Miami Vice and the prequel of Silence of the Lambs. Although Zhang Ziyi is the lead, and that she thinks she's going to get an Oscar nomination, I think Li is the one that will be on the best supporting actress cateogory come January, and Michelle Yeoh has a shot at it too, since she gave her most feminine performance to date. There's been a lot of gossip about the casting of three Chinese actresses as the leads. I can understand that it may not be appropiate or convincing, especially they don't look Japanese and the accent is not right. I wonder if Lucy Liu could have been a better choice to play Sayuri, since she would have no problem delivering lines in fluent English with a Japanese accent. Or better yet, they could hire Meryl Streep to coach the three actresses a thing or two about accents. The bottom line is Zhang Ziyi has bankability, and she's the "It Girl", despite the fact she's also the most disliked, overrated, overused, and overexposed actress from all of Asia.Memoirs of a Geisha is the story of a lengendary geisha named Sayuri. It chronicles the days when she was sold to become a maid in the geisha house at the age of nine, to becoming the most famous geisha after enduring a great deal of hardship and pain. Her only sister was sold to the "Pleasure District", and never reconnected when she ran away. Her fisherman father and mother died of poor health. The broken hearted Chiyo decides to become a geisha, and she was fortunate enough to have Mammeha(Michelle Yeoh) as her mentor, and from then she changed her name to Sayuri. In her early days as a maid, she had been treated badly by the nasty and cruel Hatsumono(Gong Li), and in order to retaliate, she must become a great geisha. Hatsumono and Mammeha are rivals, and Mammeha intended to use Sayuri to maintain her status and power in the geisha world, and of course to upstage Hatsumono one day.Hatsumono is a rebellious geisha, and she secretly has forbidden sexual and romantic encounters. The increasingly successful Sayuri provokes her to the point of verbal and physical attacks. Her plans to sabotage Sayuri's career eventually fails and she loses her status as the top geisha. Gong Li had several mesmerizing moments, such as the one when Mother(played by the scene stealing Kaori Momoi) confronted her for violating the rules of forbidden love. Also her final showdown with Zhang Ziyi when she set the house on fire was totally Oscar-calibre stuff! At first, I found that Li's accent is very off, but I just ignored it since her performance was so striking.Michelle Yeoh gets to tackle a role that's totally anti-action chick. Mammeha is a wise senior geisha who is kind to Sayuri, but she can be ruthless and aggressive at times. Yeoh excells in conveying the femininity and sophisticated aspects of a geisha. Compare to the role Hatsumono, Mammeha is kind of subdued and less powerful. She still gets the same amount of screentime as Li, and she obviously has no problem speaking English fluently.The Japanese actors all have supporting roles. Youki Kudoh(Pumkin) is a bit of a comic relief. Her role is "dumb geisha"who became very "Americanized during the World War 2. Ken Watanabe is rather underexposed as Chairman, the love interest of Sayuri. I find that the development of their romance is not convincing, and it was disappointing that their love scene was deleted. Suzuka Ohgo who played Chiyo is quite impressive, and she appeared in the first half an hour of the film. Tsai Chin who was memorable in The Joy Luck Club plays the dutiful housekeeping Auntie, and she had a few strong scenes to work with.Zhang Ziyi's performance just came across as monotone, unlike the intense and subtle Gong Li and Michelle Yeoh. The only time she's amazing is when she does the dance numbers. She's good at making herself look like an amateur when she's playing scenes with other veteran actors. For instance, the scene when she almost got raped, or did she?, she was not convincing at all. I really don't understand why Rob Marshall thought she was the most suitable actress to play Sayuri? I agree with one critic who considered her performance like watching an ESL play.I am sure this film is most likely going to get the following Oscar nominations: Best Supporting Actress(Gong Li, Michelle Yeoh, Kaori Momoi), Best Costume Design, Best Production Design, Best Original Score, and Best Cinematography. By the way, it just occured to me that Julie Taymor(Titus, Frida) could have been a better choice to direct this film. She's better as a visionary and dramatic director than Marshall.

reviewText: I'm not sure we're all seeing the same movie here. One comment I keep hearing is that the actresses did not perform well, and I cannot comprehend it.
